title: How to write a letter to myself and receive it in the future - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ve done this successfully. It’s important that you put the letter somewhere where it won’t accidentally get thrown away. I put mine in a treasured book, since we never throw books away in our family. There was the possibility that we might have donated the book or sold it to a used book store eventually, so I lucked out in that I picked the right book for this task. It would be safer to put it in a safety deposit box, or a fire safe. Be sure to date the outside for the time when you’d like to open it. Date it far enough in advance that you’ll have forgotten the contents entirely. I’d make it for at least five years, if not ten or twenty. It’s very possible that you’ll forget all about it and miss the ‘open by’ date, which actually makes it even more fun to open. Do not put it in a file cabinet. There are things in my file cabinet that I’ll probably never see again. Again, since you want to open it far enough in the future that you’ll have forgotten all about it, you want to have it somewhere that you’re likely to access regularly, but infrequently. Some other options include the bottom of your underwear and/or socks drawer, taped to the back of a favorite piece of art on the wall, or taped to the back of your yearly calendar. I put a special note to myself on the bottom of an old coffee table that was handed down to me by my mother, who got it from her aunt, who got it from a garage sale by her neighbors who had a bad house fire and needed some cash for replacements and repairs on their furniture and home. Whenever we move, I always get to read it again. Since you’re thinking about fun things like this, I’d like to suggest something else. When we remodeled our bathroom in our old house, I found a bunch of rusty razors behind the old medicine cabinet. Older medicine cabinets had a slot for disposing of old razors, which fell behind it and collected over the years. It wasn’t a very nice discovery to make, and that gave me an idea. Before we put in the new medicine cabinet I wrote a little history about the house and time of the remodel, our names, and a small candle and a figurine of a meditating figure. No rusty razors for the next person who remodels! Also, when I retiled the bathroom enclosure, before I put up the backing for the tile I wrote a note on the wall about who helped me and the year and a cheerful message. It might be you who finds these sorts of things, or it might be someone else: a family member, someone who acquires your house or estate goods, etc. Don’t let that hold you back. My favorite letters by my relatives divulge intimate details and feelings, not just the facts. Enjoy!

We got you covered! If you ever fantasized about writing a letter to your future self, I’m sure you most probably written a letter to yourself and placed it somewhere in your house. In your cabinet? Or drawer? Or even somewhere in your self! However, we all know there’s a high possibility that the letters will be thrown away. (or maybe we missed the “open by” date.) There is an alternative solution to this.. Writing it digitally! There’s many email provider such as Gmail provide a scheduled function. This allows you to craft your letter in the email and send it to yourself in the future! What’s more? You don’t have to worry if your shifting house over the years. Just remember to keep that email account. Writing your letter by hand on paper is always the better option! Remember when Bruce Lee, famous American actor and martial artist, wrote his “$10 Million Dollar Goal” on paper in 1970? Writing down physically allows your brain to process what you want to achieve and it connects with yourself at a deeper level. By 1980, not only did he achieved what he wrote but even exceeded his expectation! Studies have also shown that writing things down using pen and paper proved to be effective for you to retain the information as compared to typing it on a computer. Take for instance, remember the last time when you written your “to-do-list” on your mobile or computer and you couldn’t remember or didn’t achieve it? Writing down on a piece of paper and striking it off once it’s being completed not only give you a sense of achievement but also motivation to work harder. You might want to check out Writing Letters Today For The Future and start crafting your letter physically. SG Letter is a platform whereby they will retain your letter and help you send out in the future. With their 3 simple steps procedure, anyone can write a letter to themselves, family or even friends!
